Issues.Title: Missing the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page after installed .NET SDK 6.0
Issues.Body:
* More info:
1. This is a regression, can't reproduce .NET SDK 6.0.0-alpha.1.20570.2.
2. The issue can reproduce all types project.

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET SDK 6.0 alpha.1.20574.5

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Minimal repro:**
1. Installed the latest .NET SDK 6.0 from: https://github.com/dotnet/core-sdk.
2. Create .NET Core winforms project.
3. Observe the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page.
4. Create .NET Core winform project with CLI.
5. Repeat the steps 2 & 3.

**Expected behavior:**
After step3, can select the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page.
![CoreIssue2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/103080817-9bf75c80-4611-11eb-801e-a0f63801f128.PNG)

**Actual behavior:**
After step3, missing the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page.
After step5, can select the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page.
**After step3:**
![AfterStep3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/103080763-82561500-4611-11eb-8d75-134c8402f2b9.gif)
**After step5:**
![AfterStep5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/103080774-87b35f80-4611-11eb-9123-a20b84344489.gif)
![CoreIssue1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/103080823-a0237a00-4611-11eb-996e-33461ae4d20d.PNG)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Missing the ".NET 6.0(Preview)" Target Framework item in the 'Additional information' page after installed .NET SDK 6.0" (#4410)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] The 'Edit' element in ComboBox with DropDownStyle(DropDown, Simple) should support ValuePattern and TextPattern
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net SDK 6.0.100-alpha.1.20623.10

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**More info:**
This is a regression issue, cannot repro earlier 6.0 build, regression from the fix of pull: [4185](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4185)

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core app with targeting 6.0
2. Add 2 comboBox controls with several items, and set their DropDownStyle property to DropDown, Simple separately
3. Check related Value pattern and Text pattern in Inspect for ComboBox Edit part, and in Narrator, check its behavior

**Actual behavior:**
In Inspect, LegacyIAccessible.Name IsTextPattemAvailable, IsTextPattem2Available, IsValuePattemAvailable properties are changed, and Missing Value.IsReadOnly, Value.Value, IsContentElement properties
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/103057869-aeef3a00-45db-11eb-9abb-50cdc8a5429b.png)
In Narrator, it cannot announce comboBox edit part
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/103057897-c0384680-45db-11eb-9cb6-eca451703fd7.png)

**Expected behavior:**
In Inspect, it supports ValuePattern and TextPattern for comboBox edit element
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/103058040-1c02cf80-45dc-11eb-8966-df1d29ac5cc3.png)
In Narrator, it can announce comboBox edit part.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/103057990-f5449900-45db-11eb-97d2-19de2ad69b93.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] The 'Edit' element in ComboBox with DropDownStyle(DropDown, Simple) should support ValuePattern and TextPattern" (#4409)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] An error pops up when setting a value for 'AccessibleName' property of ComboBox control
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.NET SDK 6.0.100-alpha.1.20623.10

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**More Info:**

1. This is a regression issue, it cannot reproduce on .NET SDK 6.0.100-alpha.1.20617.6.
2. Step 2 is necessary, if don't custom comBoBox's AccessibleName property, this issue cannot repro.
3. This issue cannot repro when setting ComBobox's dropDownStyle property as Simple.

**Minimal repro:**

1. Create a .NET Core Winforms application, add a ComboBox with items or without items(Duplicate items are not necessary).
2. Set a string to 'AccessibleName' property for ComboBox(eg: CB1). --- It is necessary step
3. Build and run this project.
4. Open Accessibility Insights tool, and focus on the ComboBox's list part.

Or

1. Open the attached [SampleApp.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5737802/SampleApp.zip) application in VS, then build and run it.
2. Open Accessibility Insights tool, and focus on the ComboBox's list part.

**Expected behavior:**
No error pops up.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/103051893-c7a72200-45d2-11eb-9ed3-5cba9701ec36.png)


**Actual result:**
Accessibility Insights detects an error for ComboBox's List part.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/103051116-fe7c3880-45d0-11eb-8c94-9b063d193dfa.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] An error pops up when setting a value for 'AccessibleName' property of ComboBox control" (#4408)

Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #4320


## Proposed changes
- Added support for "IKeyboardToolTip" interface in "ListViewItem" class.
- Added logic to show the tooltip for the focused ListViewItem when the user switches between items 

## Customer Impact
Before:

## Regression?

## Risk

- Minimal

- Manually

Issues.Title: The focus rectangle for drop down list of ComboBox control doesn't include the "Vertical" scroll bar with Inspect tool
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.NET SDK 6.0.0-alpha.1.20570.2

* More info:
The issue also can reproduce with Accessibility insights tool.

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
 Yes, the issue can reproduce .NET 4.8, ,can't reproduce 4.7.2. 

**Minimal repro:**
1. Extract the application build & run it.[FraTesting1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5732859/FraTesting1.zip)
2. Open the Inspect / Accessibility Insights tools.
3. Expand the drop down list by pressing the F4 or Alt + Down arrow.
4. Try to focus on the drop down list, and observe the focus rectangle.

**Expected behavior:**
The focus rectangle include the "Vertical" scroll bar.
![Expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/102950988-c8728200-4506-11eb-86f6-9987e35cb26f.PNG)

**Actual behavior:**
The focus rectangle doesn't include the "Vertical" scroll bar.
![Actual](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/102950996-cc9e9f80-4506-11eb-8d41-701161e839c7.PNG)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The focus rectangle for drop down list of ComboBox control doesn't include the "Vertical" scroll bar with Inspect tool" (#4404)

Issues.Title: Erro on choose image in a picture box
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
 5.0.101

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**


When trying to choose the image of a Picture Box, in the properties windows, and the images in the resources are like "Embedded in .resx", this error is displayed: "Object reference not set to an instance of an object."

**Expected behavior:**
Show the dialog box for selecting the image.

**Minimal repro:**
Just try to select the image through the properties window, and the image inside Resources is in Persistence set to "Embedded in .resx"
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Erro on choose image in a picture box" (#4403)

Issues.Title: ControlBox (maximize, minimize, and close button)  is not visible on MainMenu when maximizing child form
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.NET 5.0.1

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
 No

**Problem description:**

I have windows desktop application where the main form is MdiParent form with IsMdiContainer = true, and MainMenuStrip = MenuStrip.
When I open the child form and maximize it, the ControlBox (maximize, minimize, and close button) on the right side of MainForm-MainMenu is not visible, only when I move cursor on this part of MainMenu it shows very thin buttons.
With .Net Code 3.1 and the same settings, my application doesnâ€™t have this problem, ControlBox is visible in MainMenu and normal size.
Also, this works with .Net Framework 4.8.

![dotNet3 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22772163/102506385-5374f780-4083-11eb-9477-5a93760844ab.PNG)
![dotNet5 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22772163/102506400-5839ab80-4083-11eb-985b-87600d7c1d71.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ControlBox (maximize, minimize, and close button)  is not visible on MainMenu when maximizing child form" (#4388)

Issues.Title: Trouble matching StatusBar layout with StatusBarStrip controls
Issues.Body:
Following up from twitter: https://twitter.com/clairernovotny/status/1340455330577330176

I've been having trouble trying to fixi the sizing of the statusstrip labels. StatusBar was removed in .NET 3.x and the strip version's don't layout the same.

Top: StatusBar
Bottom: strip... blank stuff isn't sized statically and setting autosize false doesn't work.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1427284/102713719-41b86d80-4298-11eb-886f-c2ece0487252.png)

The idea is that the variable/fill-sized portion is on the left, and there are a few items that should be fixed-width that are aligned to the right. Some of those items have their text set to null/empty sometimes.

If I turn autosize off, then the item doesn't even show up.

To repro, clone https://github.com/RssBandit/RssBandit/

The relevant code is here: https://github.com/RssBandit/RssBandit/blob/main/source/RssBandit/WinGui/Forms/WinGUIMain.cs#L1223-L1273

Note that the WinForms designer doesn't load.... so need to do this all by hand and run to test. Set the Package project as the startup and run that for testing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Trouble matching StatusBar layout with StatusBarStrip controls" (#4398)

Issues.Title: [5.0.101] Published single file binary crashes on startup with 0x80070002 in EnableVisualStyles()
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->
5.0.101

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
<!-- Yes / No -->
No

**Problem description:**

<!--
    Describe the current behavior, what is wrong or not working as expected.
    Provide as much information as possible, including callstack for crashes/exceptions, screenshots or animations.
  -->
Publishing a single file binary produces a binary that just crashes on startup when launched from explorer. Launching cmd and then starting the exe from there, actually runs.

Not publishing for single file also works correctly.

This worked on 5.0.0 release.

```
System.IO.FileNotFoundException

The system cannot find the file specified. (0x80070002)
```

**Expected behavior:**
App works

**Minimal repro:**
1. Clone https://github.com/SteamDatabase/ValveResourceFormat
2. `cd GUI && dotnet publish`

We have builds on appveyor as well (GUI.zip) that are broken: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/xPaw/valveresourceformat/builds/36727211/artifacts

---

I created this issue in winforms because I suspect https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4177 could be the culprit. If not, could this be moved to runtime repo please.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[5.0.101] Published single file binary crashes on startup with 0x80070002 in EnableVisualStyles()" (#4397)

Issues.Title: ListBox ScroolIntoView implementation behavior is not consistent to native ListBox behavior
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 6.0
<!-- e.g. 3.0 Preview1, or daily build number, use `dotnet --info` -->

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No
<!-- Yes / No -->

**Problem description:**
- `ListBox` `ScrollIntoView` implementation  is more complicates than it need to be - it scrolls an item to the bottom of a ListBox
![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/102604299-08b3b800-4135-11eb-9aed-81c97c695523.gif)


**Expected behavior:**
- `ListBox` should have the same behavior as in .NET Framework or Win32 - scroll an item to the top of a ListBox
![2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/102604308-0baea880-4135-11eb-800d-cb89a5fcbb53.gif)



**Minimal repro:**
- Create a .NET 6.0 app
- Add a ListBox to the app
- Add some items to the ListBox (e.g. 10 items)
- Set a size for the ListBox to see a part of the items and see a vertical scrollbar
- Run the app and use Inspect to call ScrolIntoView method
- Compare with .NET Framework behavior
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ListBox ScroolIntoView implementation behavior is not consistent to native ListBox behavior" (#4392)

4. The issue can't reproduce .NET Framework 4.8.

Issues.Title: Do not create accessible objects until owner control is created
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently an accessibility object can be created before its owning control is materialised (i.e. have a valid `Handle`):
```cs

// .NET 5.0 sample

var button = new Button();                     // handle is not yet created
button.AccessibilityObject.DoDefaultAction();  // accessible object is created

form.Controls.Add(button);
form.Show();                                   // button.Handle is created
```

Such design places a lot of responsibility on SDK to constantly check and guard against accessing an owner control and its handle before their are fully created and live.
 
A lot of work has been done in response to https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/issues/3062, which added a lot of code (e.g. https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/3432), and has a perf impact (as negligible as it may be). However with the steady stream of accessibility-related work there is a significant overhead in implementing guards and rails against accidental handle access.







**Describe the solution you'd like and alternatives you've considered**

It makes no sense to access an accessibility object before its owner is materialised, i.e. a non existent control can't be navigated to or inspected in any accessibility tools (e.g. Inspect or AI4Win).

We should consider the following:
1. not creating an instance of accessibility object until its owner is fully materialised and has a valid `Handle`,
2. removing all unnecessary null checks and handle checks in `ControlAccessibleObject` and its descendants
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Do not create accessible objects until owner control is created" (#4390)
